I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
Cambodia for the Greater Mekong Subregion: Cambodia Northwest Provincial Road Improvement 
Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

2. 
Cambodia, which has one of the highest incidences of poverty in Southeast Asia has had 
good  overall  macroeconomic  figures  in  recent  years,  recording  an  average  of  11.1%  economic 
growth  in  2004–2007  although  inflation  rose  sharply  in  2008.  Despite  the  current  global  financial 
crisis,  Cambodia  needs  to  sustain  this  economic  growth,  of  which  subregional  cooperation  is  an 
integral  part.  Enhanced  subregional  economic  cooperation  requires  improved  connectivity  across 
countries  and  between  centers  of  economic  activity.  For  Cambodia,  improved  links  between 
Thailand  and  the  northwest,  west,  and  southwest  are  pivotal  to  this  economic  growth. 
Northwestern  Cambodia  has  a  high  poverty  level,  and  the  provincial  road  network  is  vitally 
important  for  facilitating  economic  growth,  enhancing  rural  access  that  supports  the  economic 
activity  of  northwestern  Cambodia,  and  providing  a  link  with  Thailand  to  facilitate  subregional 
connectivity. 
 
3. 
This  Project  forms  part  of  the  priority  projects  identified  by  Cambodia  under  the  southern 
economic corridor flagship initiatives in 2004. The Project is included in the Vientiane Plan of Action 
for  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Development  (2008–2012),  which  was  adopted  by  the  Greater 
Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  leaders  at  the  Third  GMS  Summit  2008.  The  summit  supported  the 
strategic  thrusts  of  completing  key  parts  of  the  GMS  transport  network  and  transforming  these 
corridors into fully fledged economic corridors. The Project will serve as another transnational corridor 
linking Thailand with Cambodia, and will connect with the main corridor linking Bangkok, Phnom Penh, 
Ho  Chi  Minh  City,  and  Vung  Tau.  It  will  also  support  the  GMS  transport  strategy  by  improving 
subregional  connectivity  between  Thailand  and  Cambodia  at  O'smach, 
thereby  enhancing 
subregional  transport  and  trade.  In  northwestern  Cambodia  the  Project  will  provide  reliable  all-year 
access  from  provincial  towns  and  rural  areas  to  markets,  employment,  and  social  services  such  as 
advanced health and education facilities, and also access to historical and natural cultural sites. The 
Project  road,  which  is  linked  to  about  722  kilometers  (km)  of  rural  roads  rehabilitated  under  the 
Northwestern  Rural  Development  Project, 1  will  enhance  economic  and  social  activities  of  the 
northwestern areas by reducing production and transport costs, increasing private investment, raising 
agricultural activities, and supporting development of the tourism sector. The feasibility study for the 
Project  was  prepared  through  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  the 
Government of Cambodia, in 2005.2 
 
A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

4. 
Road is the principal transport mode for the movement of goods and people in Cambodia, 
and between countries within the GMS. Roads are critical to social and economic development in 
Cambodia,  especially  in  the  project  areas  where  roads  are  the  only  available  transport  mode. 
Cambodia's  road  network  comprises  39,400  km  of  roads  that  are  categorized  as  national, 
provincial, and rural. The 4,800 km of national roads connect the capital Phnom Penh to the main 
international  border  crossings  and  the  provincial  capitals,  while  the  6,600  km  of  provincial  roads 
connect  a  provincial  center  to  adjacent  provincial  or  district  centers.  The  national  and  provincial

However,  this  represents  less  than  25%  of  the  total  national  road  length  and  the  secondary

intraprovincial links to the tertiary and rural network and to Cambodia’s largely rural population) has

the  development  of  cash-crop  production  in  the  rural  areas,  where  markets  in  many  places  are 
limited to the local area due to lack of access. It also means that provincial centers and numerous 
natural  and  cultural  sites  with  tourism  potential  are  inaccessible.  As  a  result,  many  important 
bilateral  cross-border  trade  routes  are  inaccessible,  thus  increasing  transport  costs  as  longer 
alternative  routes  have  to  be  used.  Poor  transport  connections  also  restrict  access  to  job 
opportunities, markets, schools, and health facilities. Therefore, the provision of improved roads in 
areas  where  populations  currently  do  not  have  good  access  to  such  basic  services  will  have  a 
major impact on their livelihoods. 
 
5. 
The  contribution  of  the  road  sector  to  economic  development  is  being  limited  by  poor 
maintenance  of  existing  road  assets  combined  with  rapid  traffic  growth.  As  is  the  case  in  many 
least-developed  countries  such  as  Cambodia,  poor  road  maintenance  is  an  issue  as  financial 
resources  are  not  adequately  allocated  to  maintaining  these  assets.  However,  this  situation  has 
changed  recently  in  Cambodia.  This  is  evidenced  by  the  fact  that  road  maintenance  funds  have 
increased  significantly  in  2008  to  about  $42.5  million,  increasing  from  $7.0  million  in  2006  and 
$26.0  million  in  2007.  This  is  about  20  times  the  $2  million–$3  million  total  maintenance 
expenditure  during  2002–2003.  Given  the  indirect  impacts  of  the  world  economic  downturn,  the 
budget  allocation  for  road  maintenance  in  2009  has  decreased  to  about  $32  million,  while 
projections  for  road  maintenance  for  2010  are  about  $35  million,  and  for  2011–2013  about  $40 
million per year. ADB is also providing additional support to address the road maintenance issues 
under the Road Asset Management Project3 and the proposed Provincial and Rural Roads Asset 
Management Project scheduled for approval in 2010. The current organizational structure for road 
maintenance  management,  the  technical  capacity  of  road  agencies,  and  local  contractors  will  be 
further strengthened through implementation of these road projects.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

7. 
Subregional traffic is dominated by freight and passenger road traffic. Although subregional 
traffic  is  still  modest  between  Cambodia  and  Thailand,  great  efforts  are  being  made  to  promote 
international traffic by (i) forging effective cross-border agreements to facilitate movement of goods 
and  people,  and  (ii)  establishing  border-crossing  infrastructure  and  border  access  roads. 
Cambodia and Thailand have already opened the O'smach–Chong Chom border-crossing point to 
international traffic. A memorandum of understanding (MOU) on the Bilateral Exchange of Traffic 
Rights  between  Cambodia  and  Thailand  was  signed  by  the  two  countries  during  the  Third  GMS 
Summit  in  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  in  March  2008. 6 The  intention  is  to  provide 
interim  arrangements  for  the  exchange  of  traffic  rights  between  the  two  countries  for  up  to  40 
vehicles, daily, until such time that the relevant annexes and protocols of the GMS Cross-Border 
Transport Agreement (CBTA) enter into force between the two countries (Appendix 3).7 Under this 
MOU, Cambodia and Thailand can include other border-crossing points, roads, and provinces in its 
geographic  scope  of  application. 8 Cambodia  and  Thailand  are  discussing  the  inclusion  of  the 
O'smach–Chong Chom cross-border point and associated corridor in the scope of the MOU, with 
the expectation that it will be included in the scope of application of the CBTA when the CBTA fully 
enters  into  force.  Since  the  existing  border  post  at  O'smach  is  not  adequate  to  handle  projected 
cross-border cargo and passenger traffic, as well as accommodate the requirements of the CBTA 
implementation, new border checkpoint facilities will be constructed under this Project. 
 
The increasing importance of bilateral transport and trade across the borders, as indicated 
8.

context. The Project road, National Road (NR) 56, along with NR 68 (see para. 24 regarding the

will also contribute to the rapidly increasing cross-border trade between Thailand and Cambodia. 
The  rehabilitation  of  these  roads  will  provide  a  shorter  and  more  direct  route  between  Surin  and 
Siem Reap, reducing the route from 350 km to about 200 km.

HIV Prevention and Anti-Human-Trafficking Program 

The proposed Project is located in a region with one of the highest HIV rates in the country. 
32. 
Banteay Meanchey, and particularly the border town of Poipet, is considered to be the center of the

Thailand or other provinces is a mode of survival for many Cambodians, but the steady supply of 
migrant workers willing to cross the border has sustained human trafficking activities in the project

communities.  With  the  rehabilitation  of  NR  56  and  NR  68,  there  will  be  a  large  influx  of  migrant 
workers that may increase the demand for paid (and unpaid) sexual services in the local areas.

A. 

Benefits 

54. 
The  Project  will  provide  efficient  all-weather  access  to  the  rural  areas  in  two  provinces  in 
northwestern Cambodia, to the provincial and commercial centers of Sisophon and Samraong, and 
to  Poipet  (Cambodia’s  primary  border  crossing  point  with  Thailand).  The  Project  will  promote 
economic  growth  through  increased  agricultural  production,  tourism  around  the  many  historic 
temples  throughout  the  project  area,  national  and  subregional  trade,  and  local  employment 
creation,  which  will  help  combat  widespread  poverty,  especially  in  the  rural  areas.  By  reducing 
road  transport  costs  and  improving  access  reliability,  the  Project  will  generate  substantial  direct 
economic benefits from future savings in vehicle operating costs, logistics, and road maintenance. 
It  will  also  relieve  the  isolation  of  remote  rural  areas  by  reducing  travel  costs  and  time,  and  by 
eliminating seasonal disruption of traffic during the wet season, thus enabling continuous trade and 
economic exchange and undisrupted access to schools, health services, and other services in rural 
areas.  Finally,  the  Project  will  enhance  the  impact  of  the  Northwestern  Rural  Development 
Project19 by providing crucial interconnection of rural road networks, without which the country will 
remain  fragmented  and  the  rural  roads  will,  at  best,  lead  to  small  provincial  towns,  isolating  the 
poor population and limiting the benefits of trade available to them. The main benefits of the Project 
are directly related to traffic, including (i) savings in vehicle operating costs, (ii) savings in vehicle and 
passenger  time  costs,  and  (iii)  benefits  from  traffic  generated  by  the  reduction  in  transport  costs. 
Additional benefits derived from generated traffic include (i) producer surplus benefits; (ii) additional 
tourism-related  income;  (iii)  additional  income  from  the  increased  agricultural  activity  stemming 
from  the  rehabilitation  of  the  road;  and  (iv)  social  benefits  arising  from  better  access  to  schools, 
medical  facilities,  and  other  social  services.  Derived  subregional  benefits  that  have  not  been

2. 

Social Impacts 

 
57. 
The  rehabilitation  of  NR  56  will  strengthen  the  link  between  rural  roads  under  the 
Northwestern  Rural  Development  Project  (footnote  19)  and  the  national  roads.  By  improving 
linkages  of different  road  networks,  the  Project  will  have  an  indirect impact  on  poverty  reduction. 
Key impacts of the Project include higher prices for produce and a wider span of marketing options 
for  agricultural  produce  and  increased  opportunity  for  trade  to  reduce  food  shortages.  Access  to 
NR 5 and NR 6, a main trade route with growing markets, will further increase the ability of farmers 
to  reach  a  variety  of  markets.  All-weather  access  along  NR  56  and  into the  target  villages  of  the 
Northwestern Rural Development Project will reduce the costs of accessing social services such as 
health  care  and  education.  The  effectiveness  of  government  and  other  agencies  in  providing 
services  will  significantly  improve  as  both  feeder  roads  and  the  NR  56  are  improved.  Increased 
access to these areas will facilitate a more effective outreach for organizations engaged in direct

opportunities  for  the  poor  during  road  construction  and  road  maintenance,  and  thus  will  reduce 
seasonal migration to Thailand. 
 
58. 
Common  diseases  of  the  project  area  included  dengue  fever,  malaria,  colds,  polio,  and 
whooping cough. Also, there seems to have been an increase in road accidents on NR 5 and NR 
6, where improvements are almost complete. The local communities in the proposed project area

59. 
National  HIV  Situation.  Cambodia  has  made  good  progress  in  containing  the  HIV 
epidemic, with HIV prevalence falling from 1.2% in 2003 to an estimated 0.9% in 2006. The decline 
has  been  attributed  to  the  100%  Condom  Use  Program  and  safe-sex  campaigns  that  have 
targeted sex workers and their clients.20 However, a second wave of HIV infections is being seen 
among most-at-risk populations, including indirect female sex workers,21 clients of sex workers and 
their  partners,  men  who  have  sex  with  men,  and  injecting  drug  users. 22  The  confluence  of 
unprotected paid sex and sharing contaminated needles during drug use is flagged as a key driver 
in the current epidemic. According to 2006 data, HIV prevalence among injecting drug users tested 
was at 14.3%.23 As male clients of sex workers also have sex with their wives and girlfriends, more 
traditionally low-risk women are increasingly getting infected. In 2006, among the total number of 
people  living  with  HIV,  52%  were  estimated  to  be  women  compared  to  37%  in  1998.  In  2005, 
married women accounted for almost half of new infections.24 
 
60. 
Local HIV Situation. Despite the significant progress made nationally, there are increasing 
risks of HIV epidemic in parts of the country. NR 56 and NR 68 are in a region of the country with 
one of the highest HIV rates (Banteay Meanchey is considered one of the areas with the highest 
HIV  rates  in  the  country).  Local  communities  interviewed  reported  HIV  prevalence  to  be  highest 
among the housewives of migrant workers and military personnel, emphasizing the facilitating role 
of migration and mobility in the spread of HIV.  25 In the Srey Snam district along NR 68, cases of 
sexually  transmitted  infections  are  highest  among  wives  of  migrant  workers  and  uniformed 
personnel  (military  and  police). 26  In  Oddar  Meanchey,  based  on  a  local  nongovernment 
organization providing home-based care, people living with HIV in the area can be categorized into 
three  groups:  former  military  soldiers  (30%),  former  migrant  workers  in  Thailand  (30%),  and  in-
migrants  from  other  provinces  that were  HIV  positive  prior  to  moving  to  Oddar  Meanchey  (40%). 
The  prevalence  of  sexually  transmitted  infection  is  high—one  commune  reported  a  20% 
prevalence among the total female adult population (15–49 years old). At the O'smach border, two 
Thai-owned  casinos  operate  that  encourage  sex  oriented  entertainment.  The  National  AIDS 
Authority reported that O'smach used to be the fourth-largest commercial sex hotspot in Cambodia 
before  the  border  dispute  escalated,  and  hence  it  should  be  included  in  the  HIV  intervention.  In 
Banteay  Meanchey,  HIV  prevalence  is  highest  among  migrant  workers,  military  personnel,  and 
their spouses or partners, and is concentrated in the towns of Sisophon and Poipet.

Status of Road Sector 

 
A. 
 
1. 
While Cambodia is serviced by road, rail, air, and water transport, road transport dominates 
the  domestic  transport  of  goods  and  passengers.  Roads  are  critical  to  the  social  and  economic 
development  of  Cambodia.  This  road  network  of  about  39,400  kilometers  (km)  includes  national 
roads,  or  the  primary  national  roads  (about  4,800  km),  and  provincial  roads,  or  the  secondary 
national  highways  (about  6,600  km).  The  management  of  national  and  provincial  roads  is  the 
responsibility  of  the  Ministry  of  Public  Works  and  Transport  (MPWT).  The  remaining  network  of 
about 28,000 km of rural roads is the responsibility of the Ministry for Rural Development. 
 
2. 
The primary roads consist of national roads NR 1 to NR 9, which are national highways that 
extend  from  Phnom  Penh  to  provincial  capitals  and  the  main  access  points  to  the  country.  Lesser 
national  roads  with  two-digit  numbers  are  provincial  highways  that  connect  the  provincial  capitals 
and  connect  to  minor  border  crossings  and  important  domestic  centers.  The  secondary  (provincial 
roads) and tertiary (rural and strategic roads) serve local transport needs. 
 
3. 
By  the  early  1990s,  the  years  of  civil  war  had  left  the  road  network  severely  deteriorated. 
Since  1992,  with  assistance  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  other  multilateral  and 
bilateral  development  partners,  the  Government  has  focused  on  rehabilitating  the  core  national 
infrastructure  that  is  required  for  the  economy  to  develop  in  a  sustainable  manner.  These 
development  efforts  over  the  past  16  years  have  seen  the  paved  national  road  network  extend  to 
about 2,700 km, which amounts to slightly less than 25% of the total national roads. 
 
The  road  network  was  mostly  built  before  1960,  and  has  a  significant  number  of  bridges—
4. 
there  are  about  4,000  on  the  national  roads  alone.  The  general  design  standards  cater  to  lighter 
traffic than current loads, with many existing bridges designed for gross vehicle road weights of 10 
tons  (t),  well  below  the  current  standard  of  up  to  30  t.  Bridges  have  often  collapsed  due  to 
overloading,  and  most  are  now  seriously  damaged  or  have  failed.  Most  of  the  road  network  is 
dilapidated and large parts of the country are effectively isolated during the wet season. The MPWT 
considers  that  at  least  half  of  the  primary  road  network  and  nearly  all  the  secondary  and  tertiary 
roads are in need of urgent repair, rehabilitation, or reconstruction. Road condition surveys in 2002 
confirm that 28% of the network is in good or fair condition, 35% is in poor condition, 28% is in bad 
condition, and 6% is under reconstruction or rehabilitation. 
 
5. 
Therefore, despite the improvement of national roads, many provincial and most rural roads 
are in poor condition, and parts of the country  are effectively isolated during the wet season. Until 
recently,  however,  the  secondary  national  network,  which  links  provinces  to  the  national  road 
network and provides intraprovincial links to the tertiary and rural network and to Cambodia’s largely 
rural population, has received little attention. The result is that the road network is split into networks 
of  primary  and  tertiary  roads  that  are  only  loosely  and  unreliably  interconnected.  The  situation 
hinders the development of cash-crop production in the rural areas, where markets in many places

the  poor  condition  of  such  access  roads,  many  important  bilateral  cross-border  trade  routes  are

7. 
Vehicle Numbers. Given the growing network of trafficable roads, the increasing number of 
motor vehicles in the country, and the robust growth of Cambodia’s economy, traffic has increased 
rapidly. In 2003 there were approximately 450,000 registered motor vehicles in the country, of which 
approximately 73% were motorbikes; 23% were cars, pickups, and other light vehicles; and 4% were 
trucks,  buses,  and  other  heavy  vehicles.  This  increased  to  873,000  vehicles  in  2007,  almost 
doubling in 5 years, indicating an increase of 20% annually. 
 
8. 
Overloading.  Propelled  by  the  economic  development,  overloading  of  cargo  vehicles  has 
become  a  severe  cause  of  road  damage  in  Cambodia  in  the  past  5  years.  This  leads  to  premature 
deterioration  of  road  pavements  and  threatens  the  stability  of  the  many  bridges  designed  for  light 
traffic. The legal axle load in Cambodia is 10 t. There is evidence that some trucks, particularly those 
carrying cement, take on as much as 60 t over a truck-trailer combination. A survey carried out in 1997 
identified an average axle weight of 10 t with maximum axle weights of up to 16 t. Further, the survey 
indicated that about 24% of the vehicles with two or more axles were overloaded. Enforcement of axle 
load limits in Cambodia is ongoing but weak, and thus it is essential that an effective axle load control 
program is formulated to lead to greatly extended pavement life and lower bridge maintenance costs. 
This  is  particularly  important  for  bridges,  which  constitute  a  very  large  part  of  the  network,  as 
exceptionally heavy vehicles can damage structures irreparably. 
 
9. 
Subdecree  744,  Maximum  Load  Limit  of  Transport  Vehicles  Using  the  Road  Network  in 
Cambodia, was approved by the Government on 3 September 1999. It details the load limits and sets 
penalties  for  overloading.  Such  penalties  should  reflect  actual  damage  and  discourage  overloading. 
Pavement design is based on the fact that vehicle damage to a road depends entirely on the axle load 
of those vehicles. The penalties listed in the subdecree increase only linearly with increasing loads, but 
damage to the road in reality increases exponentially as the load increases. Small increases in axle 
load above the legal limit of 10 t can result in a severe increase in damage to the road pavement. As 
far as practicable, penalties should reflect the exponential increase in damage. 
 
10.  While  the  Government  enacted  the  legislation  required  to  enforce  overloading  control  in 
2006, the MPWT, supported by the Japan International Cooperation Agency, launched an axle load 
control  program  in  2005  to  address  this.  ADB  also  supported  this  through  its  ongoing  Greater 
Mekong  Subregion:  Cambodia  Road  Improvement  Project 1 by  providing  seven  permanent  weigh 
stations  on  national  roads.  These  are  expected  to  be  operational  some  time  in  2009.  Since  this 
operation  requires  wider  coverage  to  be  effective,  this  initiative  needs  further  assistance  by 
establishing more weigh stations on national roads, with an effective enforcement scheme.

The main economic benefits of the Project are VOCs and road user time savings accruing 
to  future  normal  and  generated  traffic,  and  saving  in  future  maintenance  because  the  upgraded 
road  requires  less  costly  maintenance  than  the  existing  road.  The  HDM-4  model  was  used  to 
estimate these benefits over time. This model predicts annual-total VOC savings over the life of the 
investment  based  on  (i)  predicting  deterioration  in  the  pavement  over  time,  which  in  turn  reflects 
traffic intensity and the maintenance regime applied over time; and (ii) forecast traffic. In both the 
with-project and without-project cases, the road roughness level varies from year to year according 
to  traffic  movement  and  the  maintenance  applied.  Road  roughness  is  expressed  in  terms  of  the 
international roughness index and has a direct impact on VOCs and hence on the level of benefits.

project  condition),  benefits  were  estimated  individually  for  each  subsection  and  aggregated  to

computed outside the HDM-4 model, using Microsoft Excel.

Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 

A. 
 
The years of civil war in Cambodia left the road network severely deteriorated. Since 1992, with assistance from the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  other  multilateral  and  bilateral  development  partners,  the  Government  has  focused  on 
rehabilitation  of  the  core  national  infrastructure  that  is  required  for  the  development  of  the  economy.  Despite  the 
improvement  of  national  roads,  many  provincial  and  most  rural  roads  are  in  poor  condition  and  parts  of  the  country  are 
effectively  isolated  during  the  wet  season.  Until  recently,  the  secondary  national  network,  which  links  provinces  to  the 
national  road  network  and  provides  intraprovincial  links  to  the  tertiary  and  rural  network  and  to  Cambodia’s  largely  rural 
population, has received little attention. The road network is split into two networks—primary and tertiary roads—which are 
only loosely and unreliably interconnected. The situation hinders the development of cash-crop production in the rural areas, 
where markets in many places are limited to the local area due to lack of access. It also means that provincial centers and 
numerous natural and cultural sites with tourism potential are inaccessible. The Government’s poverty reduction strategy for 
2009–2013 (the Rectangular Strategya started in 2004 with the first phase, now in its second phase) emphasizes generating 
economic growth through the private sector, thus rehabilitation and development of the country’s physical infrastructure is a 
precondition  for  this.  ADB’s  country  strategy  for  Cambodia  for  2005–2009b  supports  ADB's  overall  strategy  for  poverty 
reduction through broad-based growth, inclusive social development, and stronger governance for sustainable development. 
Given the continuing challenges in terms of rural access and sectorwide best practices, the country strategy for the transport 
sector  has  shifted  from  large-scale  public  sector  interventions  for  national  roads  to  (i)  fostering  technical  cooperation, 
standard setting, and private investment in national transport; and (ii) supporting subregional projects that promote access to 
remote rural areas. In this context, this Project is a core intervention of ADB in the transport sector, as included in the country 
operations business plan 2008–2010,c as a Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) project. The project supports this strategy, 
particularly as it enhances connectivity, economic exchange between Cambodia and other GMS countries, and access to 
social services in remote areas. 
 
The key objectives of GMS cooperation in the transport sector, as identified by the GMS 10-Year Strategic Framework 
(2002–2012), are to (i) develop priority transport corridors critical to linking the subregion  together and promoting trade 
and investment; (ii) reduce nonphysical barriers to the movement of people, goods, and services; and (iii) formulate and 
coordinate  strategies  to  ensure  that  the  transport  corridors  evolve  into  economic  corridors,  leading  to  agricultural 
diversification, industrialization, and the creation of employment opportunities. This Project will support the GMS transport 
strategy by improving the subregional connectivity at O'smach between Thailand and Cambodia, to enhance subregional 
transport and trade. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis 
1. 
 
The majority of poor people in Cambodia live in rural areas and base their livelihoods on agricultural activities. The project 
area is located in the northwestern part of Cambodia near the border with Thailand, and includes National Road (NR) 56 in 
the provinces of Banteay Meanchey, and Oddar Meanchey. The project area has very high poverty levels of over 60%. The 
dire  poverty  situation  in  the  project  area  can  be  related  to  the  relative  physical  remoteness  and  poor  infrastructure  in  the 
area. Government services, such as health and education, rarely reach the interior and tend to be restricted to peri-urban 
areas.  Insecurity  and  lack  of  access  have  also  reduced  the  effectiveness  and  outreach  of  development  activities  by 
nongovernment  organizations.  Many  poor  people  face  food  shortages  for  several  months  and  are  vulnerable  to  external 
shocks due to reliance on subsistence agriculture and lack of access to income-earning opportunities, markets, and social 
services  during the  wet season. Food  security  is  a major concern  of  poor  people. Most farmers  are  primarily  subsistence 
farmers  growing  one  (rain-fed)  crop  a  year,  often  of  low  quality  or  yield  (significantly  lower  than  yields  in  similar  agro-
ecological  areas).  Irrigation  is  scarce  and  unreliable.  The  principle  mode  of  transport  in  Cambodia  is  by  road.  In  spite  of 
efforts to improve the Cambodian road network since the mid-1990s, it is still in poor shape. One-quarter of the national road 
network  is  in  good-to-fair  condition.  The  quality  of  the  rural  roads  deteriorate,  the  majority  of  them  are  in  poor-to-bad 
condition. The transport system in Cambodia carries the majority of passengers and cargo on its road network. The length of 
the  rural  road  network  is  approximately  28,000  kilometers,  or  about  70%  of  the  total  road  network  in  Cambodia.  The 
proposed Project aims to provide reliable all-year road access from provincial towns and agricultural rural areas to markets, 
employment,  and  social  services  in  northwestern  Cambodia.  Improved  infrastructure  will  lead  to  increased  openness  for 
communities  deprived  of  adequate  access  to  information  and  markets.  The  improved  road  will  increase  investment  and 
development programs, access to off-farm employment, and diversification of risk and vulnerability. Access to markets will 
reduce  vulnerability  to  food  shortages  and  reliance  on  subsistence  agriculture.  Enhanced  access  will  also  enable  the

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis 
 
The  vulnerability  of  the  population  in  the  area,  and  especially  of  the  poor,  is  marked  by  a  number  of  factors.  These 
include adverse demographic and socioeconomic conditions, illiteracy, poor access to drinking water and health facilities, 
and low school enrolment and attendance in comparison with the overall national situation. Adult literacy is estimated at 
46% compared with the national average of over 67%. The population with safe access to drinking water is estimated at 
less  than  7%  (compared  with  the  national  average  of  29%)  and  around  4%  are  estimated  to  have  access  to  sanitary 
latrines (compared with the national average of 15%); school attendance (5–14 age groups) is below 60% compared with 
66% for the whole country. This is indicative of high opportunity costs of children to attend school and the need to engage 
children in livelihood activities.

The incidence of disabled persons is high (2.2 per 1,000 compared with the national average of 1.5). This is a reflection 
of the prolonged civil strife and the presence of unexploded ordnance in the area. Access to credit is severely limited and 
savings  are  small,  leading  to  frequent  asset  liquidation  to  meet  crises  (most  frequently  caused  by  health  shocks). 
Reproductive  services  exist  but  are  largely  inaccessible  due  to  the  widely  dispersed  nature  of  the  population  and  long 
travel  distances  and  times  needed  to  reach  these  (especially  in  Oddar  Meanchey).  People  are  forced  to  use  multiple 
sources  of  water  with  rainwater,  water  from  dug  wells,  and  water  collected  from  ponds  and  other  surface  sources. 
Common diseases in the project area include dengue fever, malaria, colds, polio, and whooping cough. The Project will 
include a safe drinking water program for Project villages and schools as part of the civil works contract to provide safe 
drinking water to the poor households and school children. 
 
Social Risks 
The  Cambodian  Demographic  Health  Survey  2000  reveals  that  Banteay  Meanchey  is  one  of  the  provinces  with  the 
lowest level of awareness of HIV/AIDS, with 79% of respondents aware of HIV/AIDS compared to the national average of 
95%  awareness.  A  2000  sexually-induced  virus  surveillance  testing  in  Banteay  Meanchey  found  the  following  rates  of 
HIV-positive people in the groups tested: 7.3% of police, 37.3% of direct commercial sex  workers, and 4% of pregnant 
women attending antenatal clinics. While this is a decrease from previous years, it is still very high. Recent data from the 
voluntary  confidential  counseling  and  testing  sites  in  Siem  Reap  shows  that  new  HIV  infections  are  highest  among 
housewives and lowest among sex workers. In some of the districts of Siem Reap, 40%–50% of households have at least 
one family member  who migrated to Thailand for  work, and there is an increase in the number of housewives  who are 
getting  infected  by  their  husbands  who  worked  in  Thailand.f  In  Oddar  Meanchey  and  Banteay  Meanchey  provinces, 
mobile and migrant populations are a big concern. The large number of migrants who go to Thailand and other provinces 
resettle  in  the  community  when  they  are  tested  as  HIV  positive.  All  three  (Banteay  Meanchey,  Oddar  Meanchey,  and 
Siem Reap) provinces rank low in terms of women’s knowledge of HIV prevention. 
 
Due to its proximity to Thailand, the area is prone to labor mobility, both inward and outward. A large number of people 
migrate to the towns and to Thailand in search of work, usually illegally. Frequently the brokers come to the villages to 
recruit  young  men  and  women.  They  migrate  for  mainly  economic  reasons,  in  response  to  wage  differentials  between 
Thailand and Cambodia, food shortages, and underemployment. Most of the migrants are poor or very poor young men 
and women with inadequate landholdings. Short-term migration takes place in response to underemployment during off-
peak agricultural seasons and serves as a coping mechanism for food insecurity. The seasonal migrant laborers work just 
across the border in agriculture for very low  wages and under harsh conditions. Some of the long-term migrants—both 
men  and  women—travel  deep  into  Thailand  and  engage  in  unskilled  employment  activities  such  as  construction  work, 
manufacturing, and food processing activities. Young men and women migrants also become victims of human trafficking 
and  are  forced  to  become  sex  workers.  One  of  the  major objectives  of  the  Project  is  to  enhance  economic  integration, 
and increase mobility and intra- and cross-border trade. While labor mobility is already high, mobility can be expected to 
increase both to and from this area. Given the high incidence and low awareness of HIV/AIDS in Banteay Meanchey, and 
an expected increase of truck drivers going through the area, there is a risk of further spread of HIV/AIDS to and from the 
project area. The high level of labor migration to Thailand poses a significant risk of human trafficking. In order to reduce 
the risk of human trafficking and HIV/AIDS, an awareness raising program on HIV prevention and anti-human trafficking 
will be included in the Project. The HIV/AIDS program will be targeted to the construction camps, vehicle operators and 
truck drivers, sex workers, and villages and towns in the Project districts of NR 56 and NR 68. In addition, in the project 
area construction workers, the commune and district health clinics, and medical centers will be provided with HIV/AIDS 
and  sexually  transmitted  diseases  medical  packages.  The  ADB  Technical  Assistance  for  HIV  Prevention  and

Introduction 

A. 
 
The  Greater  Mekong  Region:  Cambodia  Northwest  Provincial  Road  Improvement  Project  is 
1.

2. 
The Project consists of the reconstruction of National Road (NR) 56 located in Banteay Meanchey 
Province in the northwestern part of Cambodia. The road is about 113 kilometers (km) long. Generally, the 
existing horizontal alignment will be retained, however a realignment of NR 56 will be carried out to bypass 
the  Banteay  Chhmar  temple.  The  temple  is  protected  by  royal  decree  and  the  surrounding  area  has  a 
series of protective zones which severely restrict the improvement of NR 56. The realignment will avoid 
these zones. The realignment is 11 km long and increases the overall length of NR 56 by approximately 
0.5 km. Many years of civil disturbance have caused the road to be neglected; it is now in poor condition 
with some bridges being on the point of collapse. Replacement of bridges and some structures along NR 
56  has  already  been  completed  under  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion:  Cambodia  Road  Improvement 
Project.2 Implementation of the Project will provide all-weather access to remote and poorly serviced rural 
areas and improve community accessibility to markets and social infrastructure. It will promote subregional 
economic and social development in the project area. 
 
3. 
Improvement  of  the  existing  cross-border  facility  at  O'smach  in  Oddar  Meanchey  Province  on 
the border with Thailand will also be undertaken. New cross-border facilities will be constructed to meet 
Greater Mekong Subregion requirements and will be suitable for one-stop processing. The site will be 
located at the southern end of an existing 0.9 km cement concrete pavement, which will extend to the 
border gate with shopping outlets located to the east and a hotel casino on each side of the road. The 
site for the facility is approximately 4 hectares (ha). Truck and cargo processing will be separated from 
private  vehicle  and  bus  movements.  The  development  will  provide  new  customs,  CAMCONTROL 
(police force controlling the boarder post), and quarantine and administration buildings.

Physical Resources  

 
Cambodia's climate is dominated by the monsoon which causes distinct wet and dry seasons. 
4. 
The southwest monsoon brings the rainy season from May to October. The northeast monsoon brings 
drier and cooler air from early November to March, then hotter air prevails in April and early May. The 
southern part of the country has a 2-month dry season whereas the northern areas have a 4-month 
dry  season.  Temperatures  are  fairly  uniform  throughout  the  country,  with  only  small  variations  from 
the  average  annual  temperature  of  around  28°C.  January  is  the  coldest  month  and  April  is  the 
warmest.  Most  of  Cambodia’s  regions  have  an  average  wind  velocity  of  less  than  3  meters  per 
second.

Samraong, most parts of the land along the road are alluvial fans while pediments are found mostly at

6. 
Forests make up a major part of the country's natural resources. Hill evergreen, tropical rain,

NR 56 runs on the edge of the BCPL, which consists of flat plains covered by degraded dry

NR 56 within the BCPL where woodland forest has been removed for about 1 km on either side of the 
road. The villages of Sras Chrei, Banteay Chhmar Cheung, Banteay Chhmar Tbong, and Thmar Dek 
Kes are situated along NR 56 within the BCPL, and three villages are situated inside the BCPL near 
the Banteay Chhmar temple. In 2002, the governor of Banteay Meanchey province, with reference to 
the royal decree on the protection of natural area and in recognition of the needs of the local people

to  Banteay  Chhmar,  the  Government  would  allow  them  to  continue  to  use  and  occupy  the  land 
located  alongside  NR  56  for  a  distance  of  400  m  on  both  sides  of  NR  56;  (ii)  from  Thmar  Pourk  to 
Boeung Trakourn, they would be allowed to use land 5 km on both sides of the road; and (iii) at the 
border  with  Thailand,  they  would  be  allowed  to  use  land  3  km  on  both  sides  of  the  road.  Concrete 
posts have been placed to mark the extent of the community area with respect to NR 56; these are 
set back about 400 m from NR 56. The works on NR 56 will have no impact on the BCPL. According 
to the Ministry of Environment, no rare or endangered species exist in the BCPL.

Cultural Resources 

 
8. 
NR 56 also goes around the Banteay Chhmar temple at chainage 57 km. The temple is a large 
ancient  cultural  monument,  dating  back  to  the  Angkor  Wat  period.  It  is  governed  by  a  special  royal 
decree  dated  11  March  2003.  The  decree  indicates  there  are  three  zones  of  protection  for  Banteay 
Chhmar: Zone 1 (core zone, needs high conservation), Zone 2 (buffer zone, rich with artifacts which 
constrain  inappropriate  development),  and  Zone  3  (support  zone  which  is  for  socioeconomic 
development). As the temple is nominated for World Heritage status, the Ministry of Culture and Fine 
Arts  indicated  that,  due  to  the  proposed  United  Nations  Educational,  Scientific  and  Cultural

the  three  zones  of  protection,  and  to  avoid  adverse  impacts  to  the  temple,  the  Project  will  involve 
construction of an 11-km bypass on sparse scrubland.
